claim: The equator divides the Earth into East and West

supporting.text: The equator is an imaginary line that divides the Earth into the Northern and Southern Hemispheres, not East and West.

attacks.text: The equator is an imaginary line that divides the Earth into the Northern and Southern Hemispheres, not East and West.
The Prime Meridian, not the equator, is the line that divides the Earth into East and West Hemispheres.
Some cultures historically used different reference lines for East-West division, but the Prime Meridian is now the internationally accepted standard.
The Prime Meridian's location is arbitrary and was chosen by political convention rather than natural geography.

supporting.text: The Prime Meridian, not the equator, is the line that divides the Earth into the Eastern and Western Hemispheres.

attacks.text: The Prime Meridian, not the equator, is the line that divides the Earth into the Eastern and Western Hemispheres.
The equator is sometimes colloquially referred to as dividing the Earth into East and West due to its role in defining global navigation and climate zones.
Colloquial usage does not override the formal geographical definition, which clearly assigns the division of East and West Hemispheres to the Prime Meridian.
Some ancient or non-Western cartographic systems used alternative reference lines, which could include the equator for directional division.
Modern international standards (e.g., ISO 6709) and scientific consensus universally recognize the Prime Meridian as the divider of Eastern and Western Hemispheres.

supporting.text: Geographical division into East and West is based on longitudinal lines, with the Prime Meridian at 0 degrees longitude serving as the reference.

attacks.text: Geographical division into East and West is based on longitudinal lines, with the Prime Meridian at 0 degrees longitude serving as the reference.
The equator is sometimes colloquially used to divide the Earth into East and West in informal contexts, despite not being the technical standard.
Colloquial usage does not override formal geographical definitions, which are standardized for precision in navigation, mapping, and science.
Some ancient and non-Western traditions historically used the equator or other celestial references for directional division.
Modern international standards (e.g., ISO 6709) universally adopt the Prime Meridian system, rendering historical alternatives obsolete for practical purposes.

supporting.text: The equator is defined as 0 degrees latitude, while East-West division is determined by longitude, making the claim incorrect.

attacks.text: The equator is defined as 0 degrees latitude, while East-West division is determined by longitude, making the claim incorrect.

While the equator is a latitudinal line, it still serves as a reference point for global navigation and can symbolically divide the Earth into hemispheres, which may be interpreted as East-West in some contexts.
Symbolic interpretations do not change the strict geographic definitions, where East-West division is exclusively governed by longitude lines (meridians).

supporting.text: Standard maps and globes use the Prime Meridian to separate East and West, not the equator.

attacks.text: Standard maps and globes use the Prime Meridian to separate East and West, not the equator.
The equator is a natural dividing line for North and South, but East and West are arbitrary conventions based on the Prime Meridian.
Some cultures historically used the equator or other landmarks as reference points for East and West before the Prime Meridian was standardized.
Modern navigation and international agreements universally recognize the Prime Meridian as the standard reference for East and West.
